title: 112_s1671
content: The "Foreign Earnings Reinvestment Act" allows for a temporary dividends received deduction for dividends received from a controlled foreign corporation. The taxpayer may elect to apply section 965 to their last taxable year before the enactment of the Foreign Earnings Reinvestment Act or their first taxable year within a 1-year period after the enactment. This election must be made before the due date for filing the tax return for that taxable year. The taxpayer can elect to apply section 965 to their last taxable year before or first taxable year after the enactment of the Foreign Earnings Reinvestment Act. Amendments include changing dates and excluding certain amounts for deduction. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include changes to deduction determinations for prior taxable years, related party indebtedness, and base period dates. The deduction now includes current and accumulated foreign earnings. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes changes to deduction determinations for prior taxable years, related party indebtedness, and base period dates. It now includes current and accumulated foreign earnings without diminution by distributions made during the election year for all controlled foreign corporations of the United States shareholder. Conforming amendments are made to section 965(c) of the Code. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes changes to deduction determinations for prior taxable years and a bonus deduction for increasing jobs in the subsequent taxable year. Dividends taken into account under subsection (a) for the election year are subject to an applicable percentage based on the qualified payroll of the taxpayer. The term 'qualified payroll' refers to the aggregate wages paid by a corporation during a calendar year. If a taxpayer acquires a predecessor's trade or business after December 31, 2009, their qualified payroll for a calendar year will be increased. If a taxpayer acquires a predecessor's trade or business, their qualified payroll for a calendar year will increase. If the taxpayer disposes of a trade or business, their qualified payroll for the following year will decrease by the wages attributable to the disposed business. If a taxpayer disposes of a trade or business, their qualified payroll for the following year will decrease by the wages attributable to the disposed business. The text discusses amendments to the tax code regarding the exclusion of wages paid to individuals who received compensation for services performed after a certain date and were not employees of the taxpayer. Additionally, there is a provision for a reduction in benefits if employment levels are not maintained after receiving a distribution. If a taxpayer does not maintain an average employment level equal to their prior average after receiving a distribution, they must include an additional amount in their income. The amount is $75,000 multiplied by the number of employees by which the average employment level falls below the prior average. The taxpayer's average employment level is determined by the average number of full-time United States employees at the end of each month. Prior average employment is based on the average number of full-time United States employees in the 24 months before receiving a distribution. The term "full-time United States employee" is defined for this purpose. The term 'full-time United States employee' is defined as an individual working 40 hours or more per week in the United States, regardless of the employer's classification. The amendments made by this section shall apply to any trade or business acquired or disposed of by the taxpayer within a 24-month period, with aggregation rules applying to all domestic members of a controlled group. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act.
